Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Since CO2 stayed more or less constant over this time scale, so did temperature.
CO2: Volcanoes are adding more CO2 than the sinks are removing, thus Carbon sources exceed carbon sinks, causing an increase.  It will take longer than 200 years to cause a level change though.
Volcano: This scenario begins in a "snowball Earth" state--Temperature, CO2, Ice, sea level, weathering, C burial by sediments, and buried carbon release by weathering are all at level 1.  Ice level is at 5.  Volcanoes, mountains, and insolation will stay constant at level 3 throughout the entire scenario.  The planet is NOT in equilibrium (unlike all of the other scenarios)--both sinks of C are virtually shut down as is one source (buried carbon release due to weathering), but volcanoes are still releasing CO2 into the atmosphere.
Mountains: Volcanoes, mountain level, and insolation stay the same throughout this scenario.
Ice: Because temperature remained nearly constant, ice levels did to.  In addition, sea level, weathering, carbonate deposition, C burial by sedimentation, and buried C release due to weathering are all shut down in this time scale.
Sea: Because temperature (and ice level) remained fairly constant, so did sea level, weathering, and carbonate deposition.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 rose, so did temperature.  However, the ice albedo feedback keeps temperature cool compared to the CO2 level.
CO2: Because C sources (constant) exceed C sinks, atmospheric carbon increased.
Ice: Because C sources (constant) exceed C sinks, atmospheric carbon increased.
Sea: Because temperature rose (and ice level fell),  sea level fell.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature rose, the planet experiences more rain, increasing the weathering rate.  Also, as ice melts, it washes huge amounts of glacially produced sediment to sea.
CO3 Desposition: Higher weathering rate washes more Ca and C to sea, increasing carbonate deposition rate, increasing the C sinks.  In all likelihood, sea life that mediate carbonate deposition are just making a comeback at this time scale, so carbonate deposition does not keep up with weathering.
Sediment: Although sedimentation rate is very high, there is not a lot of organic carbon to bury.
Weathering C Release: Weathering is moderately high, but there is not a lot of buried carbon to weather.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 rose, so did temperature.  However, the ice albedo feedback keeps temperature cool compared to the CO2 level.
CO2: Because C sources (constant) exceed C sinks, atmospheric carbon increased.
Ice: Because C sources (constant) exceed C sinks, atmospheric carbon increased.
Sea: Because temperature (and ice level) rose, so did sea level.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature rose, the planet experiences more rain, increasing the weathering rate.  Also, as ice melts, it washes huge amounts of glacially produced sediment to sea.  It is still doing so in this time period as glaciers are still melting.
CO3 Desposition: Higher weathering rate washes more Ca and C to sea, increasing carbonate deposition rate, increasing the C sinks, although not enough to move system back to equilibrium.
Sediment: By this time, life has made a comeback and is growing rapidly along the seashore.  Sediments from the glaciers wash to sea, increasing C burial during this time scale.
Weathering C Release: Weathering is moderately high, but there is not a lot of buried carbon to weather.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 rose, so did temperature.
CO2: C sinks have caught up to C sources (perhaps exceeding them).  If so their effects would show up after this time scale is over.
Ice: Temperature rise melts the remainder of the polar ice.
Sea: Because temperature rose and ice level dropped, sea level rose to its highest level.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature rose, the planet experiences more rain, increasing the weathering rate.
CO3 Desposition: Higher weathering rate washes more Ca and C to sea, increasing carbonate deposition rate to its maximum level.
Sediment: Organic carbon continues to be buried, but all the glacially produced sediment has been washed to sea, so the sedimentation rate drops off somewhat.
Weathering C Release: Weathering is high, but there is a limited amount of buried carbon to weather.
